sen.j: 散楽（さんがく）は、日本の奈良時代に大陸から移入された、物真似や軽業・曲芸、奇術、幻術、人形まわし、日本舞踊など、娯楽的要素の濃い芸能の総称。
sen.e: Sangaku, which was imported from the Asian continent into Japan in the Nara period, is the collective name of various amusement arts including, without limitation, mimicry, acrobatics/stunt, trick, magic, puppet show and Japanese dancing.

Sangaku, which was imported from the Asian continent into Japan in the Nara period, is the collective name of various amusement arts including, but not limited to, mimicry, acrobatics/stunt, trick, magic, puppet show and Japanese dancing.

Sangaku, which was imported from the Asian continent into Japan in the Nara period, is the collective name of various amusement arts including, but not limited to, mimicry, acrobatics/stunt, trick, magic, puppet show and Japanese dancing.

sen.j: 日本の諸芸能のうち、演芸など大衆芸能的なものの起源とされている。
sen.e: Of various Japanese arts, it is regarded as the origin of popular arts such as variety show.
Of various Japanese arts, it is regarded as the origin of popular arts such as variety shows.
Of various Japanese arts, it is regarded as the origin of popular arts such as variety shows.

sen.j: 起源は西域の諸芸能とされる。
sen.e: Its origin is believed to be various arts of western region of China.
Its origin is believed to be various arts of the western region of China.
Its origin is believed to be various arts of the western region of China.

sen.j: 何世紀にも渡って、中央アジア、西アジア、アレクサンドリアや古代ギリシア、古代ローマなどの芸能が、シルクロード経由で徐々に中国に持ち込まれていった。
sen.e: Various arts of Central Asia, West Asia, Alexandria, ancient Greek and ancient Rome were introduced, via the Silk Road, into China over a period of several centuries.
Various arts of Central Asia, West Asia, Alexandria, ancient Greece and ancient Rome were introduced, via the Silk Road, into China over a period of several centuries.
Various arts of Central Asia, West Asia, Alexandria, ancient Greece and ancient Rome were introduced, via the Silk Road, into China over a period of several centuries.

sen.j: それら諸芸の総称として、また、宮廷の芸能である雅楽に対するものとして、「一定の決まりのない不正規な音楽」の意で中国の隋代に「散楽」と名付けられたという。
sen.e: It is generally said that these arts were collectively named "Sangaku" in the Sui era of China with the implication that these arts were, unlike gagaku that was a court art, "informal music with no fixed rules".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is generally said that these arts were collectively named "Sangaku" in the Sui era of China with the implication that these arts were, unlike gagaku, which was a court art, "informal music with no fixed rules".

It is generally said that these arts were collectively named 'Sangaku' in the Sui era of China with the implication that these arts were, unlike gagaku, which was a court art, 'informal music with no fixed rules.'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: しかし、実際にはもっと古く、周や漢の時代には既に散楽と呼ばれる民間の俗楽（古散楽）が行われていたとも言われている。
sen.e: Actually, however, it is believed that worldly music (old Sangaku) called Sangaku existed as early as in the Zhou or Han era.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Actually, however, it is believed that worldly music (old Sangaku) called Sangaku existed as early as the Zhou or Han era.
Actually, however, it is believed that worldly music (old Sangaku) called Sangaku existed as early as the Zhou or Han era.

sen.j: 日本へは奈良時代に、他の大陸文化と共に移入された。
sen.e: Along with other continental cultures, it was introduced into Japan in the Nara period.
Along with other continental cultures, it was introduced into Japan in the Nara period.
Along with other continental cultures, it was introduced into Japan in the Nara period.

sen.j: しかしそれより以前に、大陸から渡っていた可能性も否定できない。
sen.e: However, the possibility that it arrived from the Asian continent earlier than the above cannot be denied.
However, the possibility that it arrived from the Asian continent earlier than the above cannot be denied.
However, the possibility that it arrived from the Asian continent earlier than the above cannot be denied.

sen.j: 日本における散楽の歴史を紐解く上で資料となるのは、それが宮中で行われていた時代の史書『続日本紀』や『日本三代実録』などである。
sen.e: Materials useful for understanding the history of Sangaku in Japan are "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued) and "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts), both are the history books written in the era when Sangaku was performed at Imperial court.

Materials useful for understanding the history of Sangaku in Japan are "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued) and "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts), both are history books written in the era when Sangaku was performed at Imperial court.

Materials useful for understanding the history of Sangaku in Japan are "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued) and "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts), both are history books written in the era when Sangaku was performed at Imperial court.

sen.j: 『続日本紀』には、天平7年（735年）に聖武天皇が、唐人による唐・新羅の音楽の演奏と弄槍の軽業芸を見たという記述がある。
sen.e: In "Shoku Nihongi", there is a description stating that the Emperor Shomu enjoyed in 735 the music of Tan/Silla and acrobatics of hokoyuke (spear play) performed by Chinese.
In "Shoku Nihongi", there is a description stating that the Emperor Shomu enjoyed in 735 the music of Tan/Silla and acrobatics of hokoyuke (spear play) performed by Chinese.
In "Shoku Nihongi," there is a description stating that the Emperor Shomu enjoyed in 735 the music of Tan/Silla and acrobatics of hokoyuke (spear play) performed by Chinese.

sen.j: これが、散楽についての最初の記録とされる。
sen.e: The above is regarded as the oldest record concerning Sangaku.
The above is regarded as the oldest record concerning Sangaku.
The above is regarded as the oldest record concerning Sangaku.

sen.j: 天平年間のいずれかに、雅楽寮に散楽戸がおかれ、朝廷によって保護される芸能となった。
sen.e: Sangaku-ko (Sangaku Section) was established in utaryo (Bureau of Traditional Music) some time in Tenpyo era and Sangaku became the art that was protected by the Imperial court.
Sangaku-ko (Sangaku Section) was established in utaryo (Bureau of Traditional Music) sometime in the Tenpyo era and Sangaku became an art protected by the Imperial court.
Sangaku-ko (Sangaku Section) was established in utaryo (Bureau of Traditional Music) sometime in the Tenpyo era and Sangaku became an art protected by the Imperial court.

sen.j: 天平勝宝4年（752年）の東大寺大仏開眼供養法会には、他の芸能と共に散楽が奉納された。
sen.e: Sangaku was performed, along with other arts, on the occasion of the Buddhist ceremony to consecrate the Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple held in 752.
Sangaku was performed, along with other arts, on the occasion of the Buddhist ceremony to consecrate the Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple held in 752.
Sangaku was performed, along with other arts, on the occasion of the Buddhist ceremony to consecrate the Great Buddha of Todai-ji Temple held in 752.

sen.j: しかしその庶民性の強さや猥雑さからか、桓武天皇の時代、延暦元年（782年）に散楽戸制度は廃止された。
sen.e: Due to its nature of popularity and vulgarity, Sangaku-ko was abolished in 782, in the era of Emperor Kanmu.
Due to its popularity and vulgarity, Sangaku-ko was abolished in 782, in the era of Emperor Kanmu.
Due to its popularity and vulgarity, Sangaku-ko was abolished in 782, in the era of Emperor Kanmu.

sen.j: とはいえ宮中で全く演じられなくなったわけではない。
sen.e: Nevertheless, the abolition of Sangaku-ko doesn't necessarily mean that Sangaku was no more performed at the Imperial court.
Nevertheless, the abolition of Sangaku-ko doesn't necessarily mean that Sangaku was no longer performed at the Imperial court.
Nevertheless, the abolition of Sangaku-ko doesn't necessarily mean that Sangaku was no longer performed at the Imperial court.

sen.j: 平安時代になると、宴席で余興的に行われるようになった。
sen.e: It was performed in the Heian period as the entertainment of banquets.
It was performed in the Heian period as entertainment at banquets.
It was performed in the Heian period as entertainment at banquets.

sen.j: 例えば『日本三代実録』によると、承和3年（837年）に仁明天皇が、弄玉、弄刀（今で言うジャグリングのような曲芸）の散楽を演じさせたとの記録がある。
sen.e: In "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku", for example, there is a description stating that Emperor Ninmyo ordered in 837 to perform rodama (ball playing) and roto (sward playing) (stunt similar to current juggling).

In "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku", for example, there is a description stating that Emperor Ninmyo ordered in 837 to perform rodama (ball playing) and roto (sword playing - stunt similar to current juggling).

In "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku," for example, there is a description stating that Emperor Ninmyo ordered in 837 to perform rodama (ball playing) and roto (sword playing - stunt similar to current juggling).

sen.j: 他にも『日本三代実録』には、御霊会などの余興として散楽が演じられたとする記述があって注目される。
sen.e: Other than the above, there is a description in "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" stating that Sangaku was performed as the entertainment of goryo-e (ritual ceremony to repose of spirit of a deceased person).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Other than the above, there is a description in "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" stating that Sangaku was performed as the entertainment of goryo-e (ritual ceremony to repose of spirit of a deceased person).
Other than the above, there is a description in "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" stating that Sangaku was performed as the entertainment of goryo-e (ritual ceremony to repose of spirit of a deceased person).

sen.j: 中でも元慶4年（880年）に相撲節会の余興として演じられた散楽は、演者がほとんど馬鹿者のようで、人々を大いに笑わせたとある。
sen.e: Among the descriptions of "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku", what is noteworthy is the one stating that Sangaku performed in 880 as the entertainment of sumai no sechie (ritual performances of sumo at the Imperial court) made people burst into laughter since its performers were almost like fools.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Among the descriptions of "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku", what is noteworthy is the one stating that Sangaku performed in 880 as the entertainment of sumai no sechie (ritual performances of sumo at the Imperial court) made people burst into laughter since its performers were almost like fools.

Among the descriptions of "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku," what is noteworthy is the one stating that Sangaku performed in 880 as the entertainment of sumai no sechie (ritual performances of sumo at the Imperial court) made people burst into laughter since its performers were almost like fools.

sen.j: 当時の散楽師が曲芸だけでなく、今の狂言に通じる滑稽物真似的な芸もしていたことが窺える貴重な記録である。
sen.e: This is a precious record from which we can gather the fact that Sangaku performers at the time performed not only stunt but also humorous mimicry which led to kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle).

This is a precious record from which we can gather the fact that Sangaku performers at the time performed not only stunts but also humorous mimicry which led to kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle).

This is a precious record from which we can gather the fact that Sangaku performers at the time performed not only stunts but also humorous mimicry which led to kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle).

sen.j: 散楽戸の廃止で朝廷の保護を外れたことにより、散楽は寺社や街頭などで以前より自由に演じられ、庶民の目に触れるようになっていった。
sen.e: After the abolition of Sangaku-ko and Imperial court's protection, Sangaku was freely performed than ever before at temples/shrines or on streets and caught ordinary people's eyes.
After the abolition of Sangaku-ko and the Imperial court's protection, Sangaku was performed more freely than ever before at temples/shrines or on streets and caught ordinary people's eyes.
After the abolition of Sangaku-ko and the Imperial court's protection, Sangaku was performed more freely than ever before at temples/shrines or on streets and caught ordinary people's eyes.

sen.j: そして都で散楽を見た地方出身者らによって、日本各地に広まっていった。
sen.e: As a result, it was spread throughout Japan by provincials who saw Sangaku in Kyoto.
As a result, it was spread throughout Japan by provincials who saw Sangaku in Kyoto.
As a result, it was spread throughout Japan by provincials who saw Sangaku in Kyoto.

sen.j: やがて各地を巡り散楽を披露する集団も現れ始めた。
sen.e: Over time, groups which perform Sangaku at various places began to appear.
Over time, groups performing Sangaku at various places began to appear.
Over time, groups performing Sangaku at various places began to appear.

sen.j: こういった集団は後に、猿楽や田楽の座に、あるいは漂泊の民である傀儡師たちに、吸収、あるいは変質していった。
sen.e: Later, these groups were merged into the theatrical group of sarugaku (form of theater popular in Japan during 11th to 14th century) and/or dengaku (a style of dancing and music performed at agricultural festivals) or became wandering puppet players.

Later, these groups were merged into the theatrical group of sarugaku (form of theater popular in Japan during 11th to 14th century) and/or dengaku (a style of dancing and music performed at agricultural festivals) or became wandering puppet players.

Later, these groups were merged into the theatrical group of sarugaku (form of theater popular in Japan during 11th to 14th century) and/or dengaku (a style of dancing and music performed at agricultural festivals) or became wandering puppet players.

sen.j: 応和3年（963年）、村上天皇により、宮中では散楽の実演は全く行われなくなった。
sen.e: In the wake of the order issued by Emperor Murakami in 963, Sangaku was no more performed at the Imperial court.
In the wake of the order issued by Emperor Murakami in 963, Sangaku was no more performed at the Imperial court.
In the wake of the order issued by Emperor Murakami in 963, Sangaku was no more performed at the Imperial court.

sen.j: 以降、散楽という言葉に集約される雑芸群は、民間に広まった様々な職業芸能に引き継がれていく。
sen.e: Since then, various arts collectively called Sangaku were taken over by various professional arts that spread in the society.
Since then, various arts collectively called Sangaku were taken over by various professional arts that spread in the society.
Since then, various arts collectively called Sangaku were taken over by various professional arts that spread in the society.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に入ると、散楽という言葉もほとんど使われなくなった。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, the term Sangaku was no more in use.
In the Kamakura period, the term Sangaku was no more in use.
In the Kamakura period, the term Sangaku was no more in use.

sen.j: 散楽のうちの物真似芸を起源とする猿楽は、後に観阿弥、世阿弥らによって能へと発展した。
sen.e: Sarugaku whose origin was mimicry, one of various arts of Sangaku, later developed into noh play thanks to Kanami and Zeami.
Sarugaku whose origin was mimicry, one of various arts of Sangaku, later developed into noh play thanks to Kanami and Zeami.
Sarugaku whose origin was mimicry, one of various arts of Sangaku, later developed into noh play thanks to Kanami and Zeami.

sen.j: 曲芸的な要素の一部は、後に歌舞伎に引き継がれた。
sen.e: A part of the elements of stunt were later succeeded by kabuki (traditional performing art).
Some of the stunt elements were later inherited by kabuki (traditional performing art).
Some of the stunt elements were later inherited by kabuki (traditional performing art).

sen.j: 滑稽芸は狂言や笑いを扱う演芸になり、独自の芸能文化を築いていった。
sen.e: Humorous arts developed into kyogen or comical entertainment which built up their unique art cultue.
Humorous arts developed into kyogen or comical entertainment which built up their unique art culture.
Humorous arts developed into kyogen or comical entertainment which built up their unique art culture.

sen.j: 奇術は近世初期に「手妻」となった。
sen.e: Trick became "tezuma" (Japanese trick) in the early-modern times.
Tricks became "tezuma" in early-modern times.
Tricks became 'tezuma' in early-modern times.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 散楽のうち人形を使った諸芸は傀儡（くぐつ）となり、やがて人形浄瑠璃（文楽）へと引き継がれていった。
sen.e: Various arts of Sangaku that used puppet became kugutsu (puppet play) and over the time, it was succeeded by ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) (bunraku).
Various arts of Sangaku that used puppets became kugutsu (puppet play) and over time, it were replaced by ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater – bunraku).
Various arts of Sangaku that used puppets became kugutsu (puppet play) and over time, it were replaced by ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater – bunraku).

sen.j: このように、散楽が後世の芸能に及ぼした影響には計り知れないものがある。
sen.e: As shown above, Sangaku had an immeasurable impact on the arts of subsequent times.
As shown above, Sangaku had an immeasurable impact on the arts of subsequent times.
As shown above, Sangaku had an immeasurable impact on the arts of subsequent times.
